docs.snippet: The investigation of Antonio Gebauer and his handling of Brazilian accounts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has focused new attention on the broader question of capital flight from Latin America, an issue that has assumed increasing importance...
docs.lead_paragraph: The investigation of Antonio Gebauer and his handling of Brazilian accounts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has focused new attention on the broader question of capital flight from Latin America, an issue that has assumed increasing importance in the context of the region's four-year-old debt crisis. News of the case, which has involved allegations of the diversion of as much as $6 million in deposits, has shocked the many friends and critics here of the banker, who has had dealings with Brazil over the past 15 years. Mr. Gebauer has indicated he will contest the allegations. Intense coverage by newspapers, radio and television has treated the case as a major scandal. But the presence of ''undeclared'' Brazilian deposits in New York has not come as a surprise.

headline.main: FOCUS ON LATIN FLIGHT OF CAPITAL

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: MORGAN GUARANTY TRUST CO OF NEW YORK

byline.original: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden paid the price at the French Open today for too much success and too little planning.   Nystrom, seeded sixth here and a top-level performer on clay, lost in the first round to unseeded Paul McNamee of Australia, 1-6, 6-3,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden paid the price at the French Open today for too much success and too little planning. Nystrom, seeded sixth here and a top-level performer on clay, lost in the first round to unseeded Paul McNamee of Australia, 1-6, 6-3, 6-2, 6-0. The methodical Nystrom, who possesses the steadiest of backcourt games, very seldom loses by such a one-sided score, but more significant than the result were the apparent miscalculations that underlay it. Nystrom has had a wondrous 1986 season so far, capturing five Grand Prix singles titles. In the process he lifted his computer ranking to No. 6 in the world.

headline.main: WEARY NYSTROM IS ELIMINATED IN PARIS

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Fledgling consumer groups from developing countries met at a conference in Riverdale, the Bronx, this week to set modest goals to protect consumers in their countries.   At the same time, Consumers Union, the most influential consumer advocacy group...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fledgling consumer groups from developing countries met at a conference in Riverdale, the Bronx, this week to set modest goals to protect consumers in their countries. At the same time, Consumers Union, the most influential consumer advocacy group in America, celebrated its 50th anniversary at a glittering party in Manhattan and looked back on half a century of successful consumer lobbying. What emerged at the Bronx conference, which was organized by the International Organization of Consumers Unions, was the feeling that these nascent groups were facing many of the same fundamental issues that sparked the beginning of the American consumer movement, and the beginning of Consumers Union, a half century ago. ''What we're seeing is the international consumer movement developing strength in the same way as we developed strength,'' said Esther Peterson, who advised Presidents Johnson and Carter on consumer affairs. ''The international consumers movement now is a force to be reckoned with.''

headline.main: THE THIRD WORLD LOOKS AT CONSUMERISM

docs.snippet: The eyes of the soccer world will be on Aztec Stadium in Mexico City today when Italy plays Bulgaria in the opening game of the 13th World Cup, the quadrennial championship of the planet's most popular sport.   It is estimated that as many as three...
docs.lead_paragraph: The eyes of the soccer world will be on Aztec Stadium in Mexico City today when Italy plays Bulgaria in the opening game of the 13th World Cup, the quadrennial championship of the planet's most popular sport. It is estimated that as many as three billion people - more than half the world's population - will have watched some part of the 52-game tournament on television by the time it ends June 29. The sport they so avidly follow is played by the same rules everywhere in the world, yet the style of the game differs tremendously from continent to continent and often between neighboring countries. It may be an oversimplification to break the world into two styles of play, the northern European and the South American. But those are the basic styles - the hard tackling, body contact and relentless running of the European teams and the ball-control, individual artistry and improvisation associated with South Americans. There are, of course, myriad variations, many of which will be on view in Mexico.

docs.snippet: For several years after Soviet troops entered Afghanistan in 1979, a former editor and Information Minister in Kabul tried to get money to restore the village school system destroyed in rebel-held areas of his country.   The Afghan, Sabahuddin...
docs.lead_paragraph: For several years after Soviet troops entered Afghanistan in 1979, a former editor and Information Minister in Kabul tried to get money to restore the village school system destroyed in rebel-held areas of his country. The Afghan, Sabahuddin Kushkaki, applied unsuccessfully to the United States Agency for International Development and to major American private foundations. Every one turned him down, thinking the war would be short. Then, as the fighting continued, he and some friends happened upon an organization with the right combination of Government money, bureaucratic flexibility and anti-Communist commitment - the National Endowment for Democracy. Using Federal money, it provided $180,845 to train teachers, conduct literacy courses for rebel fighters, reopen some schools and publish new textbooks with unflattering accounts of the Soviet role in Afghan history. ''They have been giving us help without any strings attached,'' Mr. Kushkaki said on a recent visit to Washington.

headline.main: MISSIONARIES FOR DEMOCRACY: U.S. AID FOR GLOBAL PLURALISM

byline.original: By DAVID K. SHIPLER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: France has warned the Reagan Administration that its demand for immediate compensation for the loss of $600 million worth of American grain sales to Spain could delay new international trade-freeing talks planned for next September, officials have...
docs.lead_paragraph: France has warned the Reagan Administration that its demand for immediate compensation for the loss of $600 million worth of American grain sales to Spain could delay new international trade-freeing talks planned for next September, officials have disclosed. The French Government says the American insistence on getting such compensation by the end of June could result in an agricultural trade war between the United States and the European Community. French officials say they believe such a conflict would disrupt the preliminary trade talks that are to take place in Geneva in mid-July. As a result, it would be difficult to make enough progress to enable world trade ministers to begin formal negotiations when they meet at Punte del Este, Uruguay, in September.

docs.snippet: West Germany, which gave up an easy goal after only four minutes, drew even with six minutes remaining today to tie Uruguay, 1-1, in a battle between two former two-time World Cup winners.   In the other afternoon match, Paraguay defeated Iraq, 1-0,...
docs.lead_paragraph: West Germany, which gave up an easy goal after only four minutes, drew even with six minutes remaining today to tie Uruguay, 1-1, in a battle between two former two-time World Cup winners. In the other afternoon match, Paraguay defeated Iraq, 1-0, in a Group B game at Toluca on a 35th-minute goal by Julio Cesar Romero, the former Cosmos star. In a Group E night game at Nezahualcoyotl, Denmark defeated Scotland, 1-0, on Preben Elkjaer's goal in the 59th minute.

docs.snippet: Latin American negotiators meeting here today unexpectedly offered a revised regional peace treaty to the Foreign Ministers of five Central American nations.   Foreign ministers from the eight Latin American countries sponsoring the so-called...
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin American negotiators meeting here today unexpectedly offered a revised regional peace treaty to the Foreign Ministers of five Central American nations. Foreign ministers from the eight Latin American countries sponsoring the so-called Contadora treaty set no deadline for signing the new draft accord, however, appearing to leave an indefinite period for continued consultations ahead in the three-year effort to peacefully resolve Central America's conflicts. The latest version of the accord, which negotiators said they would like to see considered as a final draft, includes for the first time new proposals to limit the regional military buildup. Verification procedures are left to be defined in the future.
